AI: Hi. This is an assistant calling from Alum Rock Animal Hospital I'm following up on Button's recent appointment. Do you have a quick minute to chat?
User: Okay.
AI: Great. This should just take a few minutes. So Button came in for an exam and vaccines and was treated for dental disease grade 3. How has Button been doing overall since the visit?
User: He's been doing good.
AI: That's wonderful to hear. Since Button seems to be doing well, I'll just check on a couple of specifics to make sure everything is on track. How's Button's appetite and energy level? Eating inactive as usual?
User: Good. Yes.
AI: Great to hear that button.
User: I know.
AI: That's great to hear. Have you been able to give the medications as prescribed? Any issues with that?
User: Steve, She hasn't had any medication. Prescribed.
AI: Got it. Thanks for letting me know. Are there any new symptoms or concerns that have developed since the visit?
User: No.
AI: That's good to hear, just to confirm. Are buttons bathroom habits normal? Urinating and defecating regularly?
User: Yes. Yes.
AI: Perfect. It sounds like Button is doing really well. Just so you know, gradual improvement over several days is typical. And some ups and downs during recovery are normal. Does that match what you're seeing with Button?
User: Yes. She's normal.
AI: That's wonderful to hear. If you have any questions or concerns about Button's recovery, feel free to reach out to us at 4 0 8 2 5 8 2 7 3 5. Thanks for taking such good care of Button. Have a great day.
User: You too. Bye.

call_analysis.summary: An assistant from Alum Rock Animal Hospital called to follow up on Button's recent appointment for an exam, vaccines, and dental disease treatment. The owner reported Button is doing well with normal appetite, energy, and bathroom habits, clarifying that no medication was prescribed. The assistant confirmed Button's good recovery and provided contact information for any future concerns.

AI: Hi. This is an assistant calling from Alum Rock Animal Hospital. I'm following up on Maya's recent appointment Do you have a quick minute to chat?
User: Hello?
AI: Hi, Joan Casillas. This is Alum Rock Animal Hospital calling about Maya's recent appointment your dog. Do you have a couple of minutes?
User: Okay.
AI: Great. This should just take a few minutes. So Maya came in for her routine vaccinations and wellness exam and was treated for osteoarthritis and degenerative joint disease. How has Maya been doing overall since the visit?
User: Doing fine.
AI: Okay. Let me ask you about some specific things. How is Maya tolerating the new Flexidan shoes? Is she eating them without any issues?
User: Yes.
AI: That's great to hear. Have you noticed any changes in Maya's mobility or comfort level since starting the joint supplement?
User: No.
AI: Okay. Just so you know, joint supplements typically take 46 weeks to show full benefits. Some dogs may show subtle improvements within 23 weeks. So it might take a little more time to see noticeable changes. There are a few things to watch for with Maya's condition. Increased limping or difficulty getting up, reluctance to walk or climb stairs, signs of pain when touched, digestive upset from the new supplement, Is Maya showing any of those signs right now? Or anything else that's concerning you?
User: No. Everything is fine. Thank you for your call.
AI: I'm glad to hear Maya's doing well. If anything comes up, feel free to reach out to us at 4 0 8 2 5 8 2 7 3 5.

call_analysis.summary: Alum Rock Animal Hospital called to follow up on Maya's recent appointment for vaccinations, a wellness exam, and treatment for osteoarthritis and degenerative joint disease. The owner reported Maya is doing fine, tolerating her Flexidan chews, and hasn't shown significant changes from the joint supplement yet. The hospital advised that the supplement can take 4-6 weeks to show full benefits and confirmed Maya is not exhibiting any concerning signs.

calls.transcript:
AI: Hi. This is an assistant calling from Alum Rock, an Hospital. I'm following up on Louie's recent appointment. Do you have a quick minute to chat?
User: Yep.
AI: Great. Should just take a few minutes. So Louie came in for an ear examination and was treated for otitis externa, How has Louie been doing overall since the visit?
User: Okay. So far?
AI: Okay. That's good to hear. Let me ask you about some specific things to make sure everything is on track. How are Louie's ears looking? Is there still discharge or that strong odor we noticed today?
User: I need ochre, but yeah, it's gone away.
AI: That's great to hear that the odor has gone away. Sounds like Louie's ears are improving. Have you been able to give him the Ottomax ear drops and prednisolone pills as directed? Is he letting you handle his ears for the drops? Alright. It sounds like things are going okay with the medications.
User: Yes.

call_analysis.summary: An Alum Rock Hospital assistant called to follow up on Louie's recent appointment for otitis externa. The user reported that Louie is doing okay, the strong ear odor has gone away, and they are administering the prescribed Ottomax ear drops and prednisolone pills. This indicates Louie's condition is improving and the treatment plan is being followed.

dynamic_variables.next_steps:
DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS FOR SHADOW

ABOUT TODAY'S VISIT
Shadow came in for treatment of a facial swelling and some intestinal concerns. We performed a surgical procedure to address the facial issue and placed a drain to help with healing. She also received treatment for intestinal parasites and did very well under anesthesia.

DIAGNOSIS
Facial abscess and intestinal parasites

WHAT WE DID TODAY
• Surgical drainage of facial abscess
• Penrose drain placement
• Antibiotic injections
• Pain medication injection
• Treatment for intestinal parasites

MEDICATIONS
• Clavamox - 62.5mg/ml
• Gabapentin - 50mg/ml
• Panacur - 222mg for 3 days
• Nexgard Combo for Cats - 5.6-16.5lbs

FOLLOW-UP
• Please schedule a follow-up 14 days for Suture removal

ADDITIONAL NOTES
Drug counselling provided

If you have any questions, please contact our clinic.
dynamic_variables.procedures: Surgical drainage and closure of left mandibular abscess, Anesthesia: Acepromazine 10mg/ml 0.01ml IM, Atropine 1/120gr 0.2ml IM, Ketamine 100mg/ml 0.8ml IM, Inhalant anesthesia: Isoflurane, Endotracheal intubation with 3.5mm tube, Monitoring: Pulse oximeter and continuous EKG
dynamic_variables.treatments: Clipped, cleaned and surgically scrubbed left mandible area, Penrose drain placed, Flushed with Betadine, Skin closed with Braunamide 3/0 SI sutures, Injection Ampicillin 200mg/ml - 0.9ml SQ, Injection Baytril 22.7mg/ml - 0.9ml SQ, Injection Torbugesic 10mg/ml - 0.18ml SQ
dynamic_variables.medications: Clavamox 62.5mg/ml , Gabapentin 50mg/ml , Panacur (fenbendazole) 222mg , Nexgard Combo for Cats 5.6-16.5lbs
dynamic_variables.visit_reason: EXAM abscess on left side of face, scabbing at base of tail, worms in stool, indoor/outdoor cat
dynamic_variables.clinical_notes: Surgical monitoring was within normal limits. Needs surgical correction for abscess.
dynamic_variables.follow_up_date: Tissue recheck in 4 days, Suture removal in 14 days

AI: Hi. This is an assistant calling from Alum Rock Animal Hospital. I'm following up on Chula's recent appointment Do you have a quick minute to chat?
User: Yes.
AI: Great. This should just take a few minutes. Chula came in for of course, take your time. Let me know when you're ready.
User: Hold on. I'm sorry. I'm ready.
AI: No problem at all. Chula came in for an exam and was treated for changes in eating and drinking habits. How has Tula been doing overall since the visit?
User: She's been doing okay. Um,
AI: Alright.
User: she's just started yeah.
AI: Got it. Let me ask you about a couple of specific things. Has chulas increased eating and drinking improved at all since yesterday's visit?
User: Okay. It stay the same.
AI: Thank you for letting me know. Staying the same is okay for now. But we'll keep monitoring it. Have you been able to give the amoxicillin drops without any issues? And has Chula tolerated them well?
User: Yes. Yeah.
AI: That's great to hear. Just to set expectations, the increased drinking and eating may not improve immediately until we identify the underlying cause from the blood work Also, some pets may have mild stomach upset when starting antibiotics. But it sounds like Chula is handling them well. And are there any other concerns or changes you've noticed with Chula?
User: No.
AI: That's good to hear. There are just a few things to watch for. Like excessive drinking that worsens, vomiting or diarrhea after starting the antibiotics, lethargy, or any difficulty urinating. If you notice any of these, please let us know right away. Otherwise, I think that covers everything. If anything comes up, give us a call at 4 u 8 2 5 8 2 7 3 5. Thanks for taking such good care of Chula.
User: Thank you.
User: Bye bye.
AI: Thank you so much. Take care.

User: Wait. Is it this 1?

User: No.

AI: Hi. This is an assistant calling from Del Valle Pet Hospital. I'm following up on Abigail's recent appointment. Do you have a quick minute to chat?
User: Sure.
AI: Great. This should just take a few minutes. So Abigail came in for a general examination because of lethargy. Weight loss, not eating, and straining to defecate. The veterinarian suspected chronic kidney disease, pending confirmation. We performed a physical examination ordered blood work, attempted urine sample collection, did some grooming to remove mats, and administered subcutaneous fluids for dehydration, We also sent you home with anti nausea medication and an appetite stimulant. How has Abigail been doing overall since the visit?
User: Actually, Abby passed away day before yesterday.
AI: I'm so very sorry to hear that. Know how devastating this must be. And my heart goes out to you. Thank you for letting us know. Please don't hesitate to reach out to DelValley Pet Hospital if there's anything we can do to support you during this difficult time.
User: Thank you.
AI: Goodbye.

During her visit, the veterinarian noted that her incision looked okay. With a little swelling and bruising, but no signs of pain. She was sent home with gabapentin to help keep her comfortable and calm. And we discussed keeping her activity levels low to protect her abdominal sutures. How has Ruby been doing overall since the visit?
User: Uh, fine. Okay.
AI: Okay. That's good to hear. Let me ask you about a few specific things to make sure everything is on track. How's Ruby's appetite and energy level? Is she eating well and staying active?
User: Eating well. Energy, extremely high.
AI: That's great that she's eating well. As for her energy, I know it can be tricky with kittens. Especially after surgery. Keeping her activity level low is really important to protect those abdominal sutures. Is she wearing her cone consistently to prevent licking or biting at the incision?
User: Yes.
AI: Perfect. That's exactly what we wanna hear. Keeping the cone on is key to helping her heal properly. Have you noticed any changes with her incision? Like increased swelling, redness, or discharge?
User: No.
AI: Does it seem That's great news. It sounds like Ruby's recovery is going well so far. Have you been able to give her the gabapentin without any issues? Or has she been tricky about taking it?
User: Not using debit PIN. Gabapentin because it doesn't seem to work. It doesn't it's not working on her.
AI: It sounds like
User: She still has high energy with the gabapentin.
AI: Thanks for sharing that. Some kittens, like Ruby, can be very active even with gabapentin. Especially if they're naturally energetic. It's meant to help calm her and manage discomfort, but it might not fully sedate her. You can try giving it to her when she's in a quieter environment as she may be calmer when alone. If it still doesn't seem to help much, we can discuss other options with the veterinarian. Would you like me to note this for follow-up?
User: Sure.
AI: Got it. I'll make a note for the veterinarian about Ruby's high energy despite the gabapentin. In the meantime, continue keeping her activity as low as possible to protect her abdominal sutures. If you have any concerns or notice any changes, don't hesitate to call us at 9 2 5 4 4 3 6 0 0 0. Is there anything else you'd like to discuss about Ruby's recovery?
User: No. Thank you. No.
AI: You're welcome. Thanks for taking such great care of Ruby. If anything comes up or you have any concerns about Ruby, call us at 9 2 5 4 4 3 6 0 0 0. For emergencies. 9 2 5 4 4 3 6 0 0 0 is available 24 7. Have a wonderful day.
User: Thank you.

AI: It sounds like Ruby's energy is through the roof. Some pets don't respond as strongly to gabapentin for calming effects. Especially if they're naturally very active. calls.transcript:
AI: Hi. This is an assistant calling from Del Valle Pet Hospital. I'm following up on Tux's recent appointment Do you have a quick minute to chat?
User: Yes.
AI: Great. This should just take a few minutes. Tux came in for a follow-up regarding hyperthyroidism management and some upper rest
User: Okay.
AI: The veterinarian diagnosed recurrent hyperthyroidism and suspected a back bacterial upper respiratory infection. During the visit, we performed a physical exam, collected blood and urine samples, and administered a long acting antibiotic injection to help with the respiratory symptoms. And how has Tuck's been doing overall since the appointment?
User: Um, kind of same. I think, um, maybe he's better.
AI: Okay. That's helpful to know. Let me ask you a few specific questions to get a clearer picture. How is tux's appetite and energy level? Is he eating and drinking normally?
User: Yes. Um, pretty much.
AI: That's good to hear. Eating and drinking normally is a positive sign. And how about his respiratory symptoms, like the sneezing or nasal discharge? Have you noticed any improvement there?
User: No. I think it's still there.
AI: Thanks for letting me know. It can take a little time for the antibiotic to fully work. But if the nasal discharge or sneezing worsens or doesn't improve after a few days, please give us a call at 9 2 5 4 4 3 6 0 0 0. We'll want to reassess if needed. Have you been monitoring his respiratory rate during heavy sleep? As we discussed, it should stay under 30 breaths per minute.
User: Not yet.
AI: That's okay. When you have a chance, try to monitor it during his heavy sleep If it goes above 30 breaths per minute for multiple days, please contact us as we might need to consider chest x rays. Is there anything else you're concerned about? Or any questions you have regarding Tux's recovery?
User: No.
AI: Alright. Just remember to keep an eye on his symptoms. And reach out if anything changes or if you have concerns. We'll be expecting the lab results on Monday, and we'll call you with the results. If anything comes up, don't hesitate to call us at 9 2 5 4 4 3 6 0 0 0. Thanks for taking such great care of Tux.
User: Thank you.

call_analysis.summary: The call was a follow-up regarding Tux's recurrent hyperthyroidism and suspected bacterial upper respiratory infection, for which he received an antibiotic injection. While Tux's appetite and energy are normal, his respiratory symptoms persist, and the owner was advised to monitor his respiratory rate and call if symptoms worsen or don't improve. The hospital will call with lab results on Monday.
